questions.text: A patient presents with flaccid bullous lesions involving the oral cavity and the skin over the scalp, face, trunk, and extremities. He has a lesion as shown in the below Image. Acantholytic cells are seen on the Tzanck smear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pemphigus vulgaris The given clinical history of flaccid blisters with involvement of oral mucosa is suggestive of Pemphigus Vulgaris. It is an immunobullous disease ( Type 2 hypersensitivity, IgG antibodies ) that commonly present at 40 to 60 years of age. Target protein: Desmosomes Target antigen: DSG3> DSG1 Characteristics: Flaccid bullae with positive bullae spread sign and nikolsky sign. 90 to 95% of patients have oral mucosal lesions Histopathology: Acantholytic cells Suprabasal split Intact basal layer Direct immunofluorescence: Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 with a reticular pattern Treatment: High dose systemic steroids, cyclophosphamide, Rituximab

Highyeild:

Direct immunofluorescence findings in common bullous disorders Pemphigus Vulgaris Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of C3 with a reticular pattern Pemphigus Foliaceous Fishnet appearance Bullous pemphigoid Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction in bullous pemphigoid Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction zone, with a u-serrated pattern

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Bullous pemphigoid: It is characterized by tense bullae, negative Sikorsky sign and bulla spread sign with a subepidermal split. Option C. Pemphigus Foliaceus: It involves the seborrheic areas of the body. There is no oral involvement. Flaccid vesicles are present which have a tendency to heal spontaneously. Option D . Dermatitis herpetiformis: It is an inflammatory immunobullous disease of the skin and a cutaneous manifestation of coeliac disease, a gluten-sensitive enteropathy characterized by intense itch and a symmetrical blistering rash. Vesicles are often 3–5 mm in diameter or blisters develop on erythematous skin but are often eroded and crusted.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association: A. Lichen planus and malignant melanoma B. Melasma and malignant melanoma C. Psoriasis and metabolic syndrome D. Vitiligo and metabolic syndrome Select the correct answer from the given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C > D Chronic plaque psoriasis is an immune-mediated inflammatory skin disease that is strongly associated with clinical features of metabolic syndrome.

Highyeild:

Metabolic syndrome The metabolic syndrome : Metabolic disarrangement becomes a syndrome if the patient has any three of the following: Waist circumference more than 40 inches in men and 35 inches in women. Elevated triglycerides 150 milligrams per deciliter of blood (mg/dL) or greater. Reduced high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL) less than 40 mg/dL i n men or less than 50 mg/dL in Elevated fasting glucose of l00 mg/dL or greater. Blood pressure values of systolic 130 mmHg or higher and/or diastolic 85 mmHg or higher. It is seen in association with psoriasis . The strongest of these associations is seen with obesity in childhood psoriasis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Lichen planus and malignant melanoma : No association Option B . Melasma and malignant melanoma: No association Option D . Vitiligo and metabolic syndrome: Vitiligo is also associated with metabolic syndrome but psoriasis and metabolic syndrome has a stronger association.

Extraedge:

Psoriasis is associated with increased risk of Cronhn’s disease Metabolic syndrome Psychological distress Non-melanoma skin cancer Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma and Basal cell Carcinoma with high dose PUVA Hyperlipidemia Type 2 Diabetes Obesity Acute Respiratory distress (a/w erythrodermic or generalized pustular psoriasis )

questions.text: All of the following have Infections present with maculopapular rash except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Shingles (zoster) Shingles present with a Painful rash with blisters. It most often appears as a single stripe of blisters that wraps around either the left or the right side of the torso.

Highyeild:

Shingles/ Herpes zoster It occurs in secondary infection with Varicella zoster virus e reactivation of latent varicella zoster from dorsal root ganglion after primary infection- chicken pox. Characteristics: Unilateral lesion. Dermatomal involvement- most common T3 to L3 spinal segment. Mucous membrane within the Dermatome is affected. Painful, grouped vesicles over red base. Triggers for herpes zoster include Emotional stress Use of medications (immunosuppressants) Acute or chronic illness Exposure to the virus Presence of a malignancy Complication: Post Herpetic neuralgia Treatment: Amitriptyline, pregabalin, gabapentin Antiviral for painful zoster- High dose acyclovir started as early as possible 800 mg 5 times/day for 1 week

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, D, Dengue, Rubella and Measles presents as a maculopapular rash.

Extraedge:

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus: Nerve involved: Frontal branch of ophthalmic nerve (V1) Vesicles present over tip/side of nose = corneal involvement present Herpes zoster oticus: Aka Ramsay hunt syndrome Geniculate ganglion is involved Vesicles over the external auditory canal I/L facial nerve palsy and otalgia present.

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for Psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops a fever, malaise, and lesions as seen in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pustular Psoriasis The given clinical scenario shows severe widespread inflammation of the skin and small white or yellow pus-filled blisters or pustules is suggestive of Pustular psoriasis which often results upon withdrawal of steroids. Pustular psoriasis occurs on sudden withdrawal of systemic steroids. There are sterile pustules at the subcorneal level. Generalized pustules fuse to form lakes of pus or sheets of pus. The pus consists of white blood cells and is not a sign of infection. On light skin, the affected areas will appear red. Triggers: a variety of factors: sudden withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids, exposure to certain medications, infections, and Treatment: Topical emollients and steroids and Systemic therapies

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Staphylococcal infection: It can cause pustular eruptions, but they usually present with local signs of infection such as erythema, tenderness, and warmth, rather than systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise. Option C . Subcorneal pustulosis: It is a rare chronic skin condition characterized by the formation of sterile pustules on the palms, soles, and sometimes on other areas of the body. However, subcorneal pustulosis is not associated with fever or malaise, and it is not typically treated with systemic corticosteroids. Option D . Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis: It is a self-limiting skin eruption that typically occurs in response to medications, most commonly antibiotics or antifungal agents

questions.text: ABCDE is used for which skin malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malignant melanoma ABCDE is used for detecting Malignant Melanoma: Common tumors with a significant risk of metastasis. Spread of melanoma: Lymphatics and bloodstream The metastases can remain asymptomatic for months to years. Recurrence is generally diagnosed when a suspicious lesion is identified and biopsy reveals malignant melanocytes Tumor Markers: S-100, HMB-45

Highyeild:

The ABCDEs of melanoma are important physical exam points to note when evaluating a pigmented lesion: A : Asymmetry of the lesion B : Border irregularity C : Color that is not uniform D : Diameter > 6 mm (size of a pencil eraser) E : Evolving size, shape, or color Prognostic factors for primary melanoma: Thickness (Breslin index) Sentinel node status Ulceration Age and sex Mitotic rate Location Regression The presence of lymph node metastasis is the single most important prognostic index for melanoma. But in Stage 1, when Lymph nodes are not involved, then the best prognostic factor is tumor thickness.
